abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Economic Rehabilitation
            Loan Project supports the Jamaican Government's efforts
            to maintain a sound macroeconomic program and continue its
            progress toward achievement of sustainable economic growth
            and further poverty reduction in the face of multiple shocks
            which have impacted the economy, especially the decline in
            international travel to and tourism in Jamaica following the
            events of September 11, 2001. It will bridge part of the
            fiscal gap generated by the shocks, help to maintain
            spending in key social programs, and rebuild damaged
            infrastructure; support private sector-led tourism and
            related economic activities; and improve overall governance
            in the country. The loan will help the Government avoid
            cutbacks in critical expenditures, especially in social
            programs. Improved public expenditure control,
            rationalization, and governance and transparency will
            increase administrative efficiency and improve the delivery
            of public services. Reforms and actions to improve the
            framework for private sector development, including a more
            flexible labor market, will stimulate growth and create
            employment opportunities for the poor, particularly in
            tourism and tourism-linked agriculture and manufacturing.
            The report also discusses three potential risks that the
            project would face.
